The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the category of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces. This provides a framework for the reconstruction of quantum theory from a purely categorical point of view.

The Myxozoa are a diverse group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a minimal structure, with a genome that is one of the smallest reported in animals. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are critical for induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the cargo-receptor complex. We show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies.

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on the variability of maize yields in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. Our results highlight the importance of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species differ in their diets is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic LMH in semiarid African savanna. We found that LMH consumed a wide range of plant species, and that species differed in their diets. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the need for more comprehensive and taxonomically fine-grained studies of diet partitioning in LMH. (Show more)

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, the length of the crisis is negatively associated with the expected closure rate. However, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many small businesses anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris load on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the Solar System is one of the most important unsolved problems in astronomy. The study of the interstellar medium and the early Solar System is a promising approach to understand the formation of the Solar System. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are consistent with the formation of the Solar System in a period of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. This period is also supported by the discovery of the oldest meteorites.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is the most fundamental characteristic of life. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output and how they are affected by different forms of external energy supplementation. We find that all forms of external energy supplementation correlate with increased reproductive output. The greatest increase in reproductive output we observe is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output and the factors that limit it. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of domestication and allonursing in domestic animals. (Show more)

The accumulation of α-syn aggregates in oligodendrocytes is a pathological hallmark of multiple system atrophy (MSA), a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in the striatum of mice with MSA, a transgenic mouse model of MSA. VX-765 also preserves tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of mice with MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. This study also provides a proof of concept for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in the treatment of synucleinopathies. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the first line of defense against pathogens and injury. It is also the main conduit for the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also a highly dynamic structure that is constantly changing in response to the environment. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of communication channels. The goal of this study was to understand how the endothelium communicates with itself and with the rest of the body. We used a combination of imaging and mathematical modeling to understand how the endothelium communicates with itself and with the rest of the body. The results of this study have implications for understanding how the endothelium responds to injury and how it can be used to treat diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and open data has never been greater. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a rich set of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages, and are described in detail in this paper. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers, policymakers, and the public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the regulation of heart rate and blood pressure. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We also show that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the selectivity filter and the inactivation gate in other ion channels. This work also provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the selectivity filter and the inactivation gate in other ion channels.

The gut microbiome is also highly dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can change rapidly in response to diet, stress, and disease. The gut microbiome is also highly diverse, with many different species of bacteria and fungi living in the same environment. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a relatively understudied group of fungi, produce a large number of natural products, which could be used as a source of therapeutics. Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders, and social anxiety is one of the most prevalent. Here we show that anxiety influences social rank and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens, which is involved in the regulation of social behavior. We also show that the energy metabolism of the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and that this function is impaired in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture multifunctional mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is highly desired for various applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the complexity of the target behaviors and the material properties. Here, we propose a data-driven approach to synthesize multifunctional structures with multiple material phases that seamlessly collaborate to achieve complex and programmable responses. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed approach can be extended to design multifunctional devices with complex and programmable behaviors, which can be applied to a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is highly dynamic during development and in response to environmental cues. Here we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. IGF2BP1 silencing in adult human erythroid tissues causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This reversal is mediated by reduced expression of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is required for the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies and to the regulation of fetal hemoglobin expression in response to environmental cues. This work provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. (Read more)

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. Ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the mechanisms of ferroptosis regulation in cancer cells are not fully understood. Here, we show that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through SREBP1/SCD1-mediated lipogenesis. This resistance is dependent on sustained activation of mTORC1 and the induction of SREBP1 by the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2). However, these drugs are associated with a high risk of developing heart failure. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs), which is mediated by the STIM/ORAI pathway. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in hypertension. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations accelerated. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy on biodiversity. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is therefore essential to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess the performance of our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other classes of antibiotics and to other targets. It can also be used to design new molecules for other diseases.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT highstands are observed during times of high eccentricity. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Holocene climate record, but its cause is still debated. One hypothesis is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the event. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the Younger Dryas ejecta is consistent with a terrestrial origin. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the ejecta are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating that the osmium in the ejecta is derived from the crust. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules formed at the YDB site are also similar to average upper continental crust, indicating that the osmium in the spherules is also derived from the crust. The osmium in the spherules is likely derived from the Grenville Province of northeastern North America, consistent with the source of the ejecta. The osmium in the ejecta and the spherules is likely terrestrial in origin, and the 12.9-ka bolide impact is a candidate trigger of the Younger Dryas cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been studied extensively, but the impact of CTLA-4 on the development of autoimmunity in adult mice has not been investigated. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, our study provides a unique model to study the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. (Show more)

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles and to trace the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant-feeding habits. (Show more)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning approach to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrated the utility of our approach by optimizing the binding affinity of a human antibody, P36-5D2, to SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibody has ∼10- to 600-fold improved binding affinity to SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our results suggest that our approach can be used to optimize antibodies for the emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants and potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates. This approach can also be extended to other protein molecules.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results indicate that larger populations do not enhance artifact performance via CCE. We discuss the implications of these findings for the study of CCE.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the most strongly associated isoform. APOE is also highly associated with astrocyte characteristics, and APOE4 is associated with a decrease in astrocytic phagocytic capacity. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, and that this regulation is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also show that APOE4 is associated with an increase in the accumulation of complement component C1q in astrocytes, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of astrocytic synapses to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies also provide a possible mechanism for the increased AD risk associated with APOE4.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is about 1,400 km in radius and has a density of 12.0–12.5 g/cm3. It is the densest solid in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. This study provides a solution to the long-standing paradox of the inner core nucleation. The results suggest that the inner core formed by two steps: first, nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, and then, nucleation of the hcp phase. This study also provides a new perspective on the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use reduces the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduction in reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and increased addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are the subject of intense study. Here, we show that deep learning models that predict well on a large corpus of natural language fall into a small number of “architectures” that predict well on a large number of datasets. These architectures predict neural responses in reading the language of patients with epilepsy, and they predict reading times and accuracy on a standard language comprehension task. Thus, the architectures that perform best at predicting language are also those that best predict the underlying brain activity. This suggests that the mechanisms that drive them may be similar. Such similarities could be due to common principles of computation, or they could be due to the fact that the models are trained on predictive reading order, which is similar across languages.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, the stability of DL methods is still an open problem. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a fundamental paradox, which we address by introducing a classification theory of stability. We establish sufficient conditions for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs in inverse problems. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the success of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure to learn from past epidemics. The classic experiment by the social psychologist Paul Meehl is cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, the study’s design flaws were not recognized at the time and have only been brought to light in the wake of the pandemic. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research. However, the pathogen that causes the reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, a clinical reaction to the presence of leprosy, has remained a mystery. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, a pathogen that causes the same clinical reaction as M. leprae but is not closely related to it. Our findings suggest that M. lepromatosis and M. leprae have diverged from a common ancestor approximately 14 Mya, and that the two pathogens have retained many of the same functions for more than 10 Mya. This suggests that the two pathogens have retained the ability to cause disease in humans, and that the evolution of the leprosy pathogen is not complete. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the two pillars of quantum statistical mechanics, the theory that describes the statistical properties of many-body quantum systems. The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in the study of the thermodynamics of isolated quantum systems. However, the entanglement dynamics is a nonperturbative problem, which is hard to solve exactly. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is perturbative. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we find perfect agreement with the exact result. This result is a milestone in the study of the entanglement dynamics, and it opens the door to the study of entanglement in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors, which are associated with safety concerns. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on recoding the viral spike protein with synonymous suboptimal codons, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate generated high levels of spike-specific antibodies and neutralizing antibodies in hamsters. In addition, the vaccine candidate reduced lung viral loads and lung pathology, and protected hamsters from all SARS-CoV-2–associated weight loss. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is poorly understood, with the most common assumption being that rats were the main vector. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas and lice, were the primary vector of plague during the Second Pandemic. Our results challenge the assumption that rats were the main vector of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic. This study has implications for understanding the history of plague and the evolution of plague control.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains of larger animals are more likely to be discovered. Here, we show that this bias can be overcome by using the number of neurons instead of brain mass as a measure of brain size. We show that the evolution of brain size is characterized by four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria is well established, but its function in the cell as a whole is less clear. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. This study provides a mechanistic basis for the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. (Read more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is involved in many cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell morphogenesis. ADF is known to bind to actin filaments and to depolymerize them, but the mechanism by which it does so is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF binds to actin filaments and depolymerizes them in a mechanical context that is relevant to cells. We find that ADF enhances the depolymerization rate of filaments that are held in a twisted configuration, which we propose is due to a mechanical torque exerted by ADF on the filaments. This torque is enhanced by the mechanical stress of a microfluidic flow, and we propose that this mechanism is critical for ADF to depolymerize actin filaments in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of ADF’s action in cells. They also suggest that mechanical stress can be harnessed to control the dynamics of actin filaments in vitro and in vivo. This is important for understanding actin dynamics in cells and for developing new therapies for diseases caused by actin filament dysregulation.

Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is widely used in the United States and is often substituted for glucose, a sweetener found in many other foods and beverages. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for the role of fructose in the development of obesity and type 2 diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people’s emotions are transferred from one person to another. We show that this occurs even when people are not interacting in person, and even when they are not aware of the emotions that they are experiencing. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of protein in all cells, and the ribosome is the primary protein-synthesizing machine. The ribosome reads mRNA sequences and translates them into proteins. The ribosome is also a dynamic machine, and it can make chemical modifications to mRNA sequences during translation. In this work, we show that one of the most common modifications found in mRNA coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a profound impact on the ribosome’s ability to translate mRNA. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This work provides a foundation for understanding how mRNA modifications can impact the ribosome’s ability to translate mRNA. This knowledge is important for understanding how mRNA modifications can regulate protein synthesis in cells. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust across a range of demographic and socioeconomic factors, and they are also maintained over time. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is the most common cause of illness worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is a major obstacle to the development of rhinovirus vaccines. Here, we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus preferentially at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity, where rhinovirus is most prevalent, due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication and may lead to the development of rhinovirus vaccines that can be used to treat the common cold. Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment, and the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used for both motility and sensing. Here we show that pili are also used for sensing surfaces, and that this sensing is important for the pathogenicity of the bacterium. We demonstrate that pili are used for sensing surfaces by showing that pili are required for the sensing of surfaces, and that pili are required for the regulation of virulence. We also show that pili are used for sensing surfaces by demonstrating that pili are required for the sensing of surfaces, and that pili are required for the regulation of virulence. The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of the presence of toxic agricultural insecticides in surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. Here, we describe the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and can act as a reservoir for the virus. We also describe the rapid spread of the virus among deer during the winter months, when human transmission is typically low. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a more comprehensive approach to the study of emerging infectious diseases. Our study highlights the need for a more comprehensive approach to the study of emerging infectious diseases.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the problems associated with the construction of large dams in developing countries and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, which are not present in all animal models of the disease. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the initiation of the AD-related immune response. We identify a neuron-specific inflammatory profile, which is unique to Aβ-burdened neurons, and propose that the accumulation of Aβ within neurons is a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD. (Read more)

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where chickens were exploited for economic purposes. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. The best that can be done is to study the folding of a single protein at high resolution. This study of the folding of the maltose binding protein, a large protein, at high resolution by mass spectrometry provides a wealth of information about the folding process. The results suggest that the folding of the protein occurs in distinct steps, with the intermediates being the same for all of the proteins. The results also suggest that the folding of the protein occurs in a stepwise manner. This is a major advance in our understanding of protein folding. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the nucleoside monophosphates of Np4, also removes the dinucleoside tetraphosphate cap. This enzyme has a unique substrate specificity, which we show is driven by the unusual manner in which it recognizes the 5′ termini of capped RNA. Our results suggest that the removal of the cap by RppH is a critical step in the process of decapping Np4-capped RNA, which in turn is required to initiate the rapid degradation of the transcript. This process could be used to reprogram gene expression in response to stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is activated in response to infection, it can also become dysfunctional, leading to the development of a proinflammatory state that is associated with poor clinical outcomes. We show that arginine, an essential amino acid, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We demonstrate that arginine administration can restore T cell function and proliferation, decrease lymphopenia, and reduce the expansion of Treg and MDSC, which are associated with poor clinical outcomes. These results suggest that arginine could be a promising therapeutic strategy for sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a quantitative basis for the study of the impact of humans on the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state, in which the system’s response to small perturbations is independent of its initial state. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of event times, and the critical state is characterized by a power-law distribution of avalanche sizes. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is desirable to tailor its properties by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and its electronic bandgap can be completely closed. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a new method to study the relationship between elastic deformation and electronic structure. This study is expected to inspire more research on the relationship between elastic deformation and electronic structure in other materials. It is also expected to provide a new method to study the relationship between elastic deformation and electronic structure in other materials.

The discovery of a large number of nodule-specific peptides in the model legume Medicago truncatula has led to the hypothesis that these peptides may have a role in plant immunity. However, the structural and functional properties of these peptides are not known. Here, we report the solution structure of one of these peptides, NCR044, which exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We show that this peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides and penetrates the fungal cell wall and membrane, followed by accumulation in the nucleoli. This work provides insights into the structural and functional properties of these peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also demonstrates the utility of NMR spectroscopy in the structural and functional studies of plant peptides. This study also highlights the potential of NMR spectroscopy in the structural and functional studies of plant peptides. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and sperm are thought to undergo a series of molecular “hand-offs” from males to females. However, the extent of these contributions is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the FRT. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can switch the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the function of VWF in the blood.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the human virome and to investigate the role of viruses in human disease. The database is publicly available and can be used by the research community.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system, but is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The instrument is capable of providing high-resolution observations of aerosols and clouds, and is verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the instrument to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the instrument constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the ACI community.

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense debate for decades. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is important because it is thought to have had a profound effect on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is also important because it is thought to have had a profound effect on the evolution of the Earth itself. We present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the early Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth decreased over geological time. This finding is consistent with previous interpretations based on isotopic evidence. This study demonstrates the value of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Show more)

Ion channels are important for ion flow and cell signaling. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure.
