The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway for regeneration in the nervous system. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the dendrite and is enhanced by activating calcium signaling. We also show that this form of regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between DLK-independent regeneration and lesion conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. (Show more)

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of meiosis. It is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in sexually reproducing organisms. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a fundamental property of genomes, and its study has been a major focus of research in the field of molecular genetics. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that of other organisms. We find that the distribution of recombination in plants is similar to that in animals, suggesting that the mechanisms underlying the distribution of recombination in plants are conserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The identification of the main resting state networks (RSNs) has been a major challenge in the field of functional neuroimaging. Here, we used a nonfluctuating measure of brain activity, metabolic cerebral blood flow, to identify and validate the main RSNs in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired during rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Our results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is a well-known regulator of translation. Here we describe a second 5′ cap structure, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNA. We show that the NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is not associated with the poly(A) tail. The NAD+ cap may regulate mRNA stability and translation, and its presence on subsets of mRNAs suggests that it may have a role in regulating gene expression.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control could prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the DCCT, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Future studies should investigate the role of DNA-me in the long-term effects of DCCT-type therapy. This would help to elucidate the mechanisms of action of intensive glucose control and to develop new therapeutic strategies for diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and there is a critical need for the development of new therapeutic strategies. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. These findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that gut permeability is increased in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, and this alteration is associated with the composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that the gut barrier may be a target for the management of this disorder. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of fruit ripening, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is of interest for the improvement of fruit flavor. Here we identify a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of the precursor 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid to form the corresponding volatile products. This pathway is unique to tomato and is distinct from other known flavin-dependent monooxygenases in plants. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and opens the door to the development of improved tomato cultivars. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of global warming. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we find a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-moving behavior. We found that grid cells, which are essential for the formation of place memories, are strongly clustered, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells are less clustered and tend to intermingle. These results suggest that grid cells are likely to form a distinct network from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. Our findings provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and will be useful for future studies of the functional architecture of this region. (Show more)

In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of the host plant and the flowering of the parasitic dodder. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of how a plant signal can travel from a host to a parasite. This study may also have implications for the study of flowering in general. The dopamine system of the brain is involved in movement and motivation. We show that dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra form specialized arborizations that are connected to the striatum and that these formations are part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. These formations, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are composed of striosomal fibers, dopamine-containing dendrites, and other neurons and glia. The striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. Thus, the striosome–dendron bouquets are likely to be important targets for future studies of the dopamine system. (Read more)

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is a highly specialized cell type that is responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The heart rate is a critical parameter that is tightly regulated by the autonomic nervous system. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the SAN cells and is required for the generation of the heart rate. Our results reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These studies provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate the heart rate and may lead to the development of new therapies for cardiac arrhythmia. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is up-regulated by IFN-γ and lipopolysaccharide, which are known to induce the expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase, interleukin-1β, and interleukin 1 receptor antagonist. Our results suggest that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is involved in the regulation of the immune response.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. The delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNAi to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine their ability to enter plant cells and deliver the cargo. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of plant biotechnology. (Show more)

Nutrient pollution is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, the importance of small tributaries has been overlooked in the past, despite their ubiquity and potential local importance. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large lakes where they can contribute to the formation of algal blooms. Our findings highlight the need to address nutrient pollution from small tributaries, which could help to protect valuable nearshore ecosystems and the services they provide to society.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “optimal brain damage” strategy, which has been proposed to explain the emergence of consciousness.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the NMDA receptor disrupt its function and cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in the microcircuitry of the brain can alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms by which NMDAR-Ab antibodies can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This framework can be used to develop new therapeutic strategies for this devastating disease.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and the history of carbon perturbation events is a key component of the history of abrupt climate change. Here, we present a study of an abrupt carbon perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon over a large area and to an increase in seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that the event can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This study provides insights into the history of carbon perturbation events and their potential impacts on the Earth system. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme for palm oil, a commodity responsible for substantial tropical deforestation. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s largest producer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the release of proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the recycling of endosomes. The exocyst complex is involved in both processes. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex in regulating the exocytosis process is not well understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in vertebrates. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the interaction of multiple sex determination alleles produces a modular system of sexual dimorphism, where each sex determination allele produces a different phenotype. This modular system of sexual dimorphism provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination may be a general feature of sex determination systems. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct but related processes that can lead to oxidative damage: accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized by light, and accumulation of lipofuscin, which is degraded by light. We show that the redox state of the intracellular iron (Fe) pool can influence the fate of these two classes of molecules. We also show that Fe can influence the fate of the bisretinoid A2E, which is a model for the lipofuscin-derived species that can photodegrade photoreceptors. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved modular prey-capture systems that allow for the evolution of specialization on different prey types. Our results suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure, and the evolution of its distinctive morphology and function has been a focus of intense study. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology, the third metacarpal styloid process. The fossil provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of Homo-like hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a rare example of the application of a new analytical approach to the study of fossil hand anatomy. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are required for the synthesis of nucleotides. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) provides these units, but cancer cells have a defective glycine import system, which makes them highly sensitive to inhibition of SHMT. We have developed a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which are highly effective in cancer cells, but not in normal cells. We have also identified a deficiency in glycine import as a targetable metabolic defect of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These findings provide a rationale for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. They also suggest that targeting the one-carbon unit supply system may be a promising strategy for the treatment of other diseases, such as neurodegenerative disorders.

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of micronutrients. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase consumption of fruits and vegetables, which is important for meeting micronutrient needs. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets and, in particular, the role of forests.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery increasing over time. This increase in weight has led to compaction of the soil, which is detrimental to the soil’s ability to support plant growth. We show that the weight of farm machinery has increased so much that the weight of modern harvesters is now comparable to the weight of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This weight has led to compaction of the subsoil, which is now at risk of being permanently damaged. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods on land may have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm machinery.
